name: Drupal
foritself:
Yes. 

Drupal is an open source project built by a team of volunteers from around the world. Drupal doesn't have employees to provide Drupal improvements and support. Drupal acquires those valuable assets through the volunteer community members, who bring deep and diverse experience to us. Many people think these community members work mostly on Drupal code, but the truth is that they also work on documentation, marketing, user support, test results, translations, and many other contributions from people with a wide range of abilities and interests. 

"Getting Involved Guide." Drupal.org. 2011. http://drupal.org/getting-involved-guide. Accessed 12 July 2012.
brand:
The Drupal wordmark logo, Drupal.org webpages and the Drupal core installation profile all share shades of blue with the grinning, drop-shaped Druplicon. An early version of the site was called "drop.org." According to the site:

"When the logo issue came up again, Kristjan Jansen (Kika) came up with the idea of putting two sideways drops together to form an infinity symbol. When placed inside a filled circle, it resembled a face. After more work by Steven Wittens, the Druplicon was created: a stylised drop with the 'infinity' eyes, a round nose and a mischievous smile."

"History of the Druplicon logo." Drupal.org. n.d. http://drupal.org/druplicon. Accessed 12 July 2012.

fse_mission_statement: The Drupal Association is an organization dedicated to helping the open-source Drupal CMS project flourish. The association helps the Drupal community with funding, infrastructure, education, promotion, distribution and online collaboration at Drupal.org. Funds to support these programs, and the Association staff come from memberships, supporting partners, sponsorships, donations, and volunteers.

formation:
OP to FSE. Dries Buyaert started Drupal around 1998-1999. It began as an internal message board when Buyaert was a computer science doctoral student. Later, it transformed into an online messageboard, then a  website, then, finally, a software release. 

As the software gained popularity, Buyaert, Dries Knapen, and Steven Wittens were stewarding the project. Based on community input and research in the open source community, The Drupal Association was incorporated as Drupal VZW, a non-profit foundation chartered in the Netherlands. An American non-profit, DrupalCon, Inc., formed in 2009 to assist in the organization of the annual conference. In 2011, DrupalCon. Inc. formally assumed the business name "Drupal Association" and began acting as the recognized legal body charged with supporting the development and maintenance of Drupal.
history: In 2000, permanent Internet connections were at a premium for University of Antwerp students, so Dries Buytaert and Hans Snijder set up a wireless bridge between their student dorms to share Hans's ADSL modem connection among eight students. While this was an extremely luxurious situation at that time, something was missing: There was no means to discuss or share simple things. This inspired Dries to work on a small news site with a built-in web board, allowing the group of friends to leave each other notes about the status of the network, to announce where they were having dinner, or to share some noteworthy news items. The software did not have a name until the day after Dries moved out after graduation. The group decided to put the internal website online so they could stay in touch, keep sharing interesting findings, and narrate snippets of their personal lives. While looking for a suitable domain name, Dries settled for 'drop.org' after he made a typo to see if the name 'dorp.org' was still available. Dorpje is the Dutch word for "village," which was considered a fitting name for the small community. Once drop.org was established on the Web, its audience changed as the members began talking about new web technologies, such as moderation, syndication, rating, and distributed authentication. Drop.org slowly turned into a personal experimentation environment, driven by the discussions and flow of ideas. The discussions about these web technologies were tried out on drop.org itself as new additions to the software running the site. It was only later, in January 2001, that Dries decided to release the software behind drop.org as "Drupal." The purpose was to enable others to use and extend the experimentation platform so that more people could explore new paths for development. The name Drupal, pronounced "droo-puhl," derives from the English pronunciation of the Dutch word "druppel," which means "drop." To view a complete list of changes to the software since it's initial release, see http://api.drupal.org/api/drupal/CHANGELOG.txt/7/source. Accessed 12 July 2012. To learn more about the history of Drupal, see also the Drupal videos from Drupalcon (2006) in Vancouver. "History." Drupal.org. n.d. http://drupal.org/about/history. Accessed 12 July 2012.

resource:
The main resource provided is the free, open-source content management system (CMS), Drupal. Drupal divides the collaborative resource into several related areas: Drupal core, the principal sofware, bundled with a variety of modules and themes to give a good starting point for site building; Modules, which extend and customize Drupal functionality; Themes, which modify the look and feel of a Drupal site; Distributions, which provide site features and functions for a specific type of site as a single downloadable package containing the Drupal core, relevant modules, themes, and pre-defined configuration; Documentation, such as user and builder guides, glossary, FAQs, tutorials, git documentation, API reference; and Support in the form community documentation, IRC, forums, books, professional services,  and training

"Drupal.org." Drupal.org. http://drupal.org. Accessed 12 July 2012.
availability: Drupal offers the Drupal core, distributions, themes, translations, and modules.  All freely available for download from http://drupal.org/download. In order to create a Drupal website, a user needs access to the internet and server space.

tasks:
Community participation is actively encouraged. At the global level, Dries Buyaert is referred to by his first name, and the yearly DrupalCon traditionally welcomes and encourages diversity, familiarity, and originality. 

At the local level, Drupal meetups happen regularly in many cities around the world, and local Drupal communities attach their own pages and organizational materials to the larger Drupal groups site. 

Meetup organizers usually tag their profiles with their actual photographs and real names. Drupal mailing lists are actively contributed to. 

The Drupal IRC channel is always open, and a useful resource for site development questions, ranging from "What is wrong with this PHP?" to "Where is the next meetup in Los Angeles?" to "Check out this module I just made and help me work out the bugs."

The forums and comments at Drupal.org and its manifestations are usually friendly and helpful. Snarkiness is generally looked upon as bad form, though blind participation (such as asking a question that has already been answered) can be frowned upon, and on a related note, the level of technical known-how required to contribute to the forums and comments is higher than your average Google user. 

"Community." Drupal.org. n.d. http://drupal.org/community. Accessed 12 July 2012.
modularity:
The Drupal Community tasks are described as "using, building, and supporting," the Drupal project.

While those with a medium to high level of technical expertise should be able to complete tasks via a "learn by doing" mentality, those with low levels of technical expertise can be confused by the concepts and tasks required to create a Drupal site. 

However, once this basic technical skill set and know-how is acquired, community participation, theming, developing, and module-writing becomes - like the development of most technologies - a matter of time and debugging.

And with that said, because of Drupal's participatory ethos and the Drupal project's extensive documentation, Drupal is sometimes used as a pedagogical resource for technical skill development.
granularity:
Each task is developed from the ground up, from debugging code, to module testing, to site development, to maintenance. 

The level of task granularity typically increases as a member's involvement with the Drupal community becomes more involved.
metrics:
The core, site modules, and themes are in a constant state of development. Users have access to multiple versions of modules and themes through main module pages and git.

Code issues can be posted as comments or in forums. Advanced users attempt to resolve issue in comments or forums. When issue is solved, the comment or forum thread is considered "closed."

A production site is a "completion" of using the Drupal core.

summary:
Drupal is a free, open-source open source content management system used at a number of high profile websites. Drupal emerged rather organically as an effort of a very small group of founders and early enthusiasts and only formed an FSE later to manage the growth of the software: since 2011, the Drupal Association has been the legal body charged with supporting the worldwide Drupal community. 

Drupal runs on over a million sites, including WhiteHouse.gov, World Economic Forum, Stanford University, and Examiner.com. Drupal’s default installation is a database-backed web platform with file maintenance tools and a high level of security. Many developers take advantage of Drupal’s extensible architecture to go far beyond the “core” package. Drupal is a multi-user system, letting site visitors log in (as “authenticated” users) or browse the site without doing so (as “anonymous” users). Administrators control permissions, and can also assign “roles” for multiple permission levels.

Drupal site designs come from “themes”, whose visual presentation is described in standard CSS. Drupal.org hosts hundreds of free, fully customizable themes, including several “base themes.” Hundreds of volunteers contribute code to Drupal's core, and many thousands more contribute themes, ad-ons, and extensions for the platform. Drupal is licensed through the GNU General Public License, version 2 or later, which requires that derivative products be distributed under the same terms of the original Drupal code. Drupal developers collaborate online and meet at an annual conference or any number of smaller regional conferences.

http://www.acquia.com/what-is-drupal. Accessed 12 July 2012.

Byron, Angela. et al. (2009). Using Drupal. O'Reilly Publishing : Sebastopol, 2009. 

Scollan, B. (2008). Drupal usability research report." Interaction Design & Information Architecture, University of Baltimore May, 2008. 

Articles and resources are plentiful for specific projects or problems with Drupal as well as operational assistance for different versions of Drupal.
